sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying cylinder
message_1: A long, straight cylindrical wire of radius 3 mm is carrying a current of 5 A along its length. Calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the cylinder. Assume the permeability of free space is 4π × 10^-7 T m/A.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the cylinder, we can use Ampere's Law. For a long, straight wire carrying a current I, the magnetic field B at a distance r from the center of the wire can be calculated using the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^-7 T m/A), I is the current (5 A), and r is the distance from the center of the wire (10 cm = 0.1 m).

Plugging in the values, we get:

B = (4π × 10^-7 T m/A * 5 A) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

The π in the numerator and denominator cancel out, and we are left with:

B = (2 × 10^-6 T m * 5) / 0.1 m

B = 10^-5 T / 0.1 m

B = 10^-4 T

So the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the cylinder is 10^-4 T or 0.0001 T.
